elements.content: Two hydrogen-bonded interdigitated one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers (CPs) were synthesized from Cd(II) nitrate and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) with two 4-styrylpyridine (4spy) derivatives. In the solid state structure of 1D CP containing 2′-fluorostyrylpyridine (2F-4spy), a guest 2F-4spy was sandwiched between the terminal 2F-4spy ligands and the CC bonds of all the 2F-4spy are well-aligned in host–guest-host–host-guest–host- sequence infinitely. From time-dependent photoreaction studies, it has been found that the [2 + 2] photocycloaddition occurs between host–guest molecules first followed by host–host pairs in a two-step process, which resulted in the quantitative conversion of CC bond pairs to cyclobutane rings. It is a rare quantitative photoreaction between the host and guest molecules. Further, solvothermal crystallization of the final photoproduct furnished an interesting three-dimensional CP with bcg topology. Interestingly, 2NO2-4spy also furnished a similar hydrogen-bonded 1D CP with parallel orientation of olefin bonds. Although the olefin bonds satisfy the Schmidt’s criteria for photoreactivity, it was found to be photoinert under UV light. This has been attributed to the steric hindrance caused by NO2 substituent or the electron withdrawing effect.
elements.clean_text: Two hydrogen-bonded interdigitated one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers (CPs) were synthesized from Cd(II) nitrate and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) with two 4-styrylpyridine (4spy) derivatives. In the solid state structure of 1D CP containing 2'-fluorostyrylpyridine (2F-4spy), a guest 2F-4spy was sandwiched between the terminal 2F-4spy ligands and the CC bonds of all the 2F-4spy are well-aligned in host-guest-host-host-guest-host- sequence infinitely. From time-dependent photoreaction studies, it has been found that the [2 + 2] photocycloaddition occurs between host-guest molecules first followed by host-host pairs in a two-step process, which resulted in the quantitative conversion of CC bond pairs to cyclobutane rings. It is a rare quantitative photoreaction between the host and guest molecules. Further, solvothermal crystallization of the final photoproduct furnished an interesting three-dimensional CP with bcg topology. Interestingly, 2NO2-4spy also furnished a similar hydrogen-bonded 1D CP with parallel orientation of olefin bonds. Although the olefin bonds satisfy the Schmidt's criteria for photoreactivity, it was found to be photoinert under UV light. This has been attributed to the steric hindrance caused by NO2 substituent or the electron withdrawing effect.

elements.content: In the solid state structure of a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional coordination polymer, a guest 2′-fluorostyrylpyridine (2F-4spy) was sandwiched between the terminal 2F-4spy ligands and well-aligned in host−guest-host−host-guest−host- sequence infinitely. The [2 + 2] photocycloaddition occurs between host−guest molecules first followed by host−host pairs in a two-step process and resulted in the quantitative conversion of CC bond pairs to cyclobutane rings.
elements.clean_text: In the solid state structure of a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional coordination polymer, a guest 2'-fluorostyrylpyridine (2F-4spy) was sandwiched between the terminal 2F-4spy ligands and well-aligned in host-guest-host-host-guest-host- sequence infinitely. The [2 + 2] photocycloaddition occurs between host-guest molecules first followed by host-host pairs in a two-step process and resulted in the quantitative conversion of CC bond pairs to cyclobutane rings.

elements.content: The “host–guest” chemistry which has been developed by the principles of supramolecular chemistry is one of the sustained scientific interests for several decades. Several noncovalent interactions including hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions provide stabilization to the supramolecular assembly. The reactivity of these unique assemblies of the host–guest moieties provides control over their reaction products such as stereospecificity, selectivity, and other characteristics. Fujita, Stang, and others have extensively investigated the interactions between host–guest molecules for their exceptional properties and interesting reactions driven by the host framework in metal-complexes and coordination polymers (CPs). In the recent years, Kitagawa and co-workers examined several polymerization reactions in the pores of CPs where the pores or the surface of the pores help in the alignment of molecules for better reactivity and stereoselectivity over the final products. Of late, an interesting host–guest cross-polymerization also has been reported from the same group. On the other hand, photoassisted solid state structural transformations have received great attention for the last few decades due to their ease and simplicity in the synthesis of new compounds which are otherwise difficult by regular solution synthesis. In particular, solid state [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction is the most popular one for more than six decades, which furnishes highly strained cyclobutane derivatives in highly stereospecific manner. Many of these solid state [2 + 2] reactions have also been used to fine-tune the pore surface and hence the selectivity of gas molecules for the separation of gases from mixtures. However, designing such compounds is still a challenge due to poor understanding of structural dynamics during the reaction in solid state. Recently, Yang and co-workers showed a fascinating host–host and guest–guest solid state photoreactivity in a PCP and the framework dynamics. Despite the great interest in solid state [2 + 2] photoreactivity of CPs for more than a decade, photoreaction between the guest molecules with the host framework structure has rarely been studied.
elements.clean_text: The "host-guest" chemistry which has been developed by the principles of supramolecular chemistry is one of the sustained scientific interests for several decades. Several noncovalent interactions including hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions provide stabilization to the supramolecular assembly. The reactivity of these unique assemblies of the host-guest moieties provides control over their reaction products such as stereospecificity, selectivity, and other characteristics. Fujita, Stang, and others have extensively investigated the interactions between host-guest molecules for their exceptional properties and interesting reactions driven by the host framework in metal-complexes and coordination polymers (CPs). In the recent years, Kitagawa and co-workers examined several polymerization reactions in the pores of CPs where the pores or the surface of the pores help in the alignment of molecules for better reactivity and stereoselectivity over the final products. Of late, an interesting host-guest cross-polymerization also has been reported from the same group. On the other hand, photoassisted solid state structural transformations have received great attention for the last few decades due to their ease and simplicity in the synthesis of new compounds which are otherwise difficult by regular solution synthesis. In particular, solid state [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction is the most popular one for more than six decades, which furnishes highly strained cyclobutane derivatives in highly stereospecific manner. Many of these solid state [2 + 2] reactions have also been used to fine-tune the pore surface and hence the selectivity of gas molecules for the separation of gases from mixtures. However, designing such compounds is still a challenge due to poor understanding of structural dynamics during the reaction in solid state. Recently, Yang and co-workers showed a fascinating host-host and guest-guest solid state photoreactivity in a PCP and the framework dynamics. Despite the great interest in solid state [2 + 2] photoreactivity of CPs for more than a decade, photoreaction between the guest molecules with the host framework structure has rarely been studied.

elements.content: In this contribution, we report the synthesis of a photoreactive interdigitated one-dimensional (1D) CP where the olefin bonds of the guest molecules are well-aligned with those of the host molecules to produce an infinite parallel alignment of CC bond arrays in the lattice. Upon UV irradiation, [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction occurs in a stepwise manner, first between the CC bonds of the host–guest pairs and then between the olefin bonds in host–host leading to the formation of a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. The importance of the time-dependent photoreaction studies to understand the course of the reaction and its mechanism is highlighted in this work.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, we report the synthesis of a photoreactive interdigitated one-dimensional (1D) CP where the olefin bonds of the guest molecules are well-aligned with those of the host molecules to produce an infinite parallel alignment of CC bond arrays in the lattice. Upon UV irradiation, [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction occurs in a stepwise manner, first between the CC bonds of the host-guest pairs and then between the olefin bonds in host-host leading to the formation of a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. The importance of the time-dependent photoreaction studies to understand the course of the reaction and its mechanism is highlighted in this work.

elements.content: Light yellow block-shaped single crystals of [Cd(bdc)­(2F-4spy)2­(H2O)]­·2F-4spy, (1) (2F-4spy = 2′-fluoro-4-styryl-pyridine) were obtained by slow diffusion of Cd(NO3)2, 2F-4spy into the aqueous solution of Na2bdc (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). The solid state structure of 1 has been determined by single crystal X-ray crystallography, and the purity of the bulk has been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies, thermogravimetry analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis. Further 1 has also been synthesized by mechanochemical synthesis by grinding the starting materials and confirmed by comparing the PXRD patterns with those simulated from single crystal data of 1.
elements.clean_text: Light yellow block-shaped single crystals of [Cd(bdc)(2F-4spy)2(H2O)]⋅2F-4spy, (1) (2F-4spy = 2'-fluoro-4-styryl-pyridine) were obtained by slow diffusion of Cd(NO3)2, 2F-4spy into the aqueous solution of Na2bdc (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). The solid state structure of 1 has been determined by single crystal X-ray crystallography, and the purity of the bulk has been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies, thermogravimetry analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis. Further 1 has also been synthesized by mechanochemical synthesis by grinding the starting materials and confirmed by comparing the PXRD patterns with those simulated from single crystal data of 1.

elements.content: The compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4 and the asymmetric unit contains half of the molecular formula of 1, where Cd(II) has pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. The oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of two bdc ligands are chelating Cd1 along with an oxygen atom of the water molecule in equatorial plane. A crystallographic 2-fold rotation is present along the Cd1–O3 axis as shown in Figure . The connectivity of the bdc ligands generate 1D coordination polymer aligned along the crystallographic c-axis. The H atoms of the coordinated water molecules are hydrogen bonded to two carboxylate O atoms of the adjacent chains in harmony, which result in the formation of a H-bonded 1D CP layer in the bc-plane (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: The compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4 and the asymmetric unit contains half of the molecular formula of 1, where Cd(II) has pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. The oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of two bdc ligands are chelating Cd1 along with an oxygen atom of the water molecule in equatorial plane. A crystallographic 2-fold rotation is present along the Cd1-O3 axis as shown in Figure . The connectivity of the bdc ligands generate 1D coordination polymer aligned along the crystallographic c-axis. The H atoms of the coordinated water molecules are hydrogen bonded to two carboxylate O atoms of the adjacent chains in harmony, which result in the formation of a H-bonded 1D CP layer in the bc-plane (Figure b).

elements.content: The axial sites of the Cd(II) are occupied by pyridyl groups of 2F-4spy ligands along the a-axis. Further there is a guest 2F-4spy molecule sandwiched between the adjacent coordinated 2F-4spy molecules as shown in Figure . This guest molecule has been found to be disordered due to the presence of crystallographic inversion center in the middle of olefin bond. It may be noted that when 4spy was used instead of 2F-4spy, a similar interdigitated 1D CP was isolated, but the DMF and water molecules occupy the space of the guest 2F-4spy molecule in 1. The guest 2F-4spy are further stabilized by the F···F interactions with the coordinated 2F-4spy as well as π–π interactions.
elements.clean_text: The axial sites of the Cd(II) are occupied by pyridyl groups of 2F-4spy ligands along the a-axis. Further there is a guest 2F-4spy molecule sandwiched between the adjacent coordinated 2F-4spy molecules as shown in Figure . This guest molecule has been found to be disordered due to the presence of crystallographic inversion center in the middle of olefin bond. It may be noted that when 4spy was used instead of 2F-4spy, a similar interdigitated 1D CP was isolated, but the DMF and water molecules occupy the space of the guest 2F-4spy molecule in 1. The guest 2F-4spy are further stabilized by the F⋅⋅⋅F interactions with the coordinated 2F-4spy as well as π-π interactions.

elements.content: Packing of the guest 2F-4spy molecules in 1 and showing the orientations of the 2F-4spy host and guest molecules. Only one of the disordered guest molecules due to crystallographic inversion is shown here.
elements.clean_text: 2  Packing of the guest 2F-4spy molecules in 1 and showing the orientations of the 2F-4spy host and guest molecules. Only one of the disordered guest molecules due to crystallographic inversion is shown here.

elements.content: Interestingly, this guest 2F-4spy ligand is aligned parallel with the coordinated 2F-4spy ligands from the adjacent interdigitated chains with a distance of separation between the centroids of the olefinic groups of 3.71 Å. Further, the coordinated 2F-4spy ligands (i.e., hosts) are aligned in a crisscross manner, and the centroids of these olefin groups are separated by a distance of 4.65 Å which is beyond the Schmidt’s distance criterion (Figure ). Hence, it is logical to expect [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction between the host and the guest 2F-4spy if 1 is exposed to UV light, but not between the hosts, i.e., the coordinated ligands. Nonetheless, 1 undergoes quantitative [2 + 2] photo cycloaddition reaction upon UV irradiation for 2 h, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figures and ). Unfortunately our attempts to obtain single-crystals at the end of the reactions were not successful.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, this guest 2F-4spy ligand is aligned parallel with the coordinated 2F-4spy ligands from the adjacent interdigitated chains with a distance of separation between the centroids of the olefinic groups of 3.71 Å. Further, the coordinated 2F-4spy ligands (i.e., hosts) are aligned in a crisscross manner, and the centroids of these olefin groups are separated by a distance of 4.65 Å which is beyond the Schmidt's distance criterion (Figure ). Hence, it is logical to expect [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction between the host and the guest 2F-4spy if 1 is exposed to UV light, but not between the hosts, i.e., the coordinated ligands. Nonetheless, 1 undergoes quantitative [2 + 2] photo cycloaddition reaction upon UV irradiation for 2 h, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figures  and ). Unfortunately our attempts to obtain single-crystals at the end of the reactions were not successful.

elements.content: A plot of the product 2 formed versus time.

elements.content: The observed photoreactivity has been rationalized on the basis of the crystal structure packing and in the light of the literature reported, as follows. Since CPs have been shown to move during photochemical reaction, it may be assumed all these infinitely aligned CC bonds can undergo [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction equally irrespective of the distances between the CC bonds. Under these circumstances, the photoreactivity of 1 can be explained by three reaction pathways: (i) The guest ligand may react with a neighboring host ligand of one of the 1D strands, and in this process, one of the host ligands will be left unreacted as shown in Scheme . This would give rise to 66.7% of photoreaction. (ii) If the photoreaction occurs between the host ligands only, then the guest molecules will be left unreacted. This should also exhibit a maximum of 66.7% photoreactivity. (iii) Finally, if the guest ligand reacts first with a coordinated ligand (66.7% photoreactivity), this triggers structural changes and brings the olefinic bonds of the adjacent host 2F-4spy ligands closer together, and then 100% reactivity is expected and there should not be any unreacted 2F-4spy at the end of the photoreaction. In other words, [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction occurs between host–guest and host–host pairs in a sequential manner which will result in the quantitative conversion of CC bond pairs to cyclobutane rings. A two-step dimerization reaction would then be expected if the reaction follows the third reaction pathway.
elements.clean_text: The observed photoreactivity has been rationalized on the basis of the crystal structure packing and in the light of the literature reported, as follows. Since CPs have been shown to move during photochemical reaction, it may be assumed all these infinitely aligned CC bonds can undergo [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction equally irrespective of the distances between the CC bonds. Under these circumstances, the photoreactivity of 1 can be explained by three reaction pathways: (i) The guest ligand may react with a neighboring host ligand of one of the 1D strands, and in this process, one of the host ligands will be left unreacted as shown in Scheme . This would give rise to 66.7% of photoreaction. (ii) If the photoreaction occurs between the host ligands only, then the guest molecules will be left unreacted. This should also exhibit a maximum of 66.7% photoreactivity. (iii) Finally, if the guest ligand reacts first with a coordinated ligand (66.7% photoreactivity), this triggers structural changes and brings the olefinic bonds of the adjacent host 2F-4spy ligands closer together, and then 100% reactivity is expected and there should not be any unreacted 2F-4spy at the end of the photoreaction. In other words, [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction occurs between host-guest and host-host pairs in a sequential manner which will result in the quantitative conversion of CC bond pairs to cyclobutane rings. A two-step dimerization reaction would then be expected if the reaction follows the third reaction pathway.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram Showing Various Possibilities of [2 + 2] Cycloaddition Reactions between 2F-4spy in 1

elements.content: To determine the correct reaction pathway among the three proposed, the course of the photoreaction of 1 under UV light was followed with time by integrating the disappearance of the signals due to the proton of the pyridyl group of 2F-4spy at 8.87 ppm and appearance of the same proton signal of the rctt-2F-ppcb ligand at 8.77 ppm. These 1H NMR spectra were measured after dissolving the irradiated samples in DMSO-d 6 along with a drop of HNO3, at specific intervals of time (Figures and ). The percentage of photo product versus time plot shows completion of the reaction in 120 min of UV exposure with a plateau at ∼66% from 50 to 90 min (Figure ). During this period it is likely that the adjacent coordinated 2F-4spy ligands come closer for the photoreaction in the second step. This two-step process strongly supports the third reaction pathway depicted in Scheme . Further, the solid obtained after the completion of 66% of the reaction was placed in dichloromethane and stirred vigorously for 10 min and filtered. A clear solution of dichloromethane was then evaporated and no solid 2F-4spy was found. On the contrary, it was possible to extract the guest 2F-4spy in dichloromethane from the crystals of 1. Hence, it is concluded that the guest 2F-4spy was fully consumed in the first step of the dimerization process. This provided further evidence that the photo dimerization takes place between the host–guest 2F-4spy molecules and followed by host–host of the polymeric strands as shown in Scheme . In this work we have illustrated that it was possible to follow the course of the solid state [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions in the absence of single crystal data. Further this seems to be the first report to demonstrate a quantitative solid state photochemical reaction between host and guest ligands in a stepwise manner. A similar two-step photochemical reaction involving molecular movements has been proposed for the quantitative conversion of olefin bonds to cyclobutane rings in a triple-stranded ladder CP.

These 1H NMR spectra were measured after dissolving the irradiated samples in DMSO-d 6 along with a drop of HNO3, at specific intervals of time (Figures  and ). The percentage of photo product versus time plot shows completion of the reaction in 120 min of UV exposure with a plateau at ~66% from 50 to 90 min (Figure ). During this period it is likely that the adjacent coordinated 2F-4spy ligands come closer for the photoreaction in the second step. This two-step process strongly supports the third reaction pathway depicted in Scheme . Further, the solid obtained after the completion of 66% of the reaction was placed in dichloromethane and stirred vigorously for 10 min and filtered. A clear solution of dichloromethane was then evaporated and no solid 2F-4spy was found. On the contrary, it was possible to extract the guest 2F-4spy in dichloromethane from the crystals of 1. Hence, it is concluded that the guest 2F-4spy was fully consumed in the first step of the dimerization process. This provided further evidence that the photo dimerization takes place between the host-guest 2F-4spy molecules and followed by host-host of the polymeric strands as shown in Scheme . In this work we have illustrated that it was possible to follow the course of the solid state [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions in the absence of single crystal data. Further this seems to be the first report to demonstrate a quantitative solid state photochemical reaction between host and guest ligands in a stepwise manner. A similar two-step photochemical reaction involving molecular movements has been proposed for the quantitative conversion of olefin bonds to cyclobutane rings in a triple-stranded ladder CP.

elements.content: As single crystals disintegrated during this photoreaction, attempts have been made to obtain the single crystals by dissolving the 2 in 2 mL of DMF solution with the use of a few drops of 1 M HNO3. The solvothermal reaction of this solution at 90 °C for 2 days resulted in light yellow block-shaped crystals. The structural determination by X-ray crystallography revealed the formation of a new compound, [Cd3(bdc)3­(rctt-2F-ppcb)2­(DMF)2]·DMF, (3) with a 3D pillared layered framework structure. The compound is crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4, implying that the asymmetric unit has half the molecular formula. This 3D framework structure has been constructed by a trinuclear node which consists of three Cd(II) atoms aligned in a linear fashion, and the coordination environment of the central Cd(II) atom is different from the other two as shown in Figure a. The central Cd(II) is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six different bdc ligands in octahedral manner, while the terminal Cd(II) atoms are bonded to three bdc ligands, one DMF, and a rctt-2F-ppcb in distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure c). The bdc linkers are oriented in such a way that [Cd3(bdc)3] nodes form (3,3) connected 2D frame in crystallographic bc-plane, while rctt-2F-ppcb acts as a pillar connecting the adjacent layers along the a-axis (Figures ). The topological analysis of 3 reveals a rare noninterpenetrated bcg net with the short Schläfli symbol 36·414·57·6 (). In the resultant pillared-layer framework structure, the void has been occupied with DMF molecules. However, this compound exhibits poor framework stability which might be due to the coordinated solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: As single crystals disintegrated during this photoreaction, attempts have been made to obtain the single crystals by dissolving the 2 in 2 mL of DMF solution with the use of a few drops of 1 M HNO3. The solvothermal reaction of this solution at 90 °C for 2 days resulted in light yellow block-shaped crystals. The structural determination by X-ray crystallography revealed the formation of a new compound, [Cd3(bdc)3(rctt-2F-ppcb)2(DMF)2]⋅DMF, (3) with a 3D pillared layered framework structure. The compound is crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4, implying that the asymmetric unit has half the molecular formula. This 3D framework structure has been constructed by a trinuclear node which consists of three Cd(II) atoms aligned in a linear fashion, and the coordination environment of the central Cd(II) atom is different from the other two as shown in Figure a. The central Cd(II) is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six different bdc ligands in octahedral manner, while the terminal Cd(II) atoms are bonded to three bdc ligands, one DMF, and a rctt-2F-ppcb in distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure c). The bdc linkers are oriented in such a way that [Cd3(bdc)3] nodes form (3,3) connected 2D frame in crystallographic bc-plane, while rctt-2F-ppcb acts as a pillar connecting the adjacent layers along the a-axis (Figures ). The topological analysis of 3 reveals a rare noninterpenetrated bcg net with the short Schläfli symbol 36⋅414⋅57⋅6 (). In the resultant pillared-layer framework structure, the void has been occupied with DMF molecules. However, this compound exhibits poor framework stability which might be due to the coordinated solvent molecules.

elements.content: (a) Trinuclear Cd(II) node, (b) 2D layered structure, (c) 3D pillared layered structure with rctt-2F-ppcb as pillar in compound 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Trinuclear Cd(II) node, (b) 2D layered structure, (c) 3D pillared layered structure with rctt-2F-ppcb as pillar in compound 3.

elements.content: Besides, the use of 2′-nitro-4-styrylpyridine (2NO2-4spy) in the place of 2F-4spy furnished light brown crystals of [Cd(bdc)­(2NO2-4spy)2­(H2O)]·DMF (4). The coordination geometry of this compound is similar to that of 1 where Cd(II) is present in pentagonal bipyramidal geometry and the equatorial positions are chelated by the carboxylates of bdc linkers along with an aqua ligand, while the axial positions are occupied by the nitrogen atoms of the 2NO2-4spy ligands.
elements.clean_text: Besides, the use of 2'-nitro-4-styrylpyridine (2NO2-4spy) in the place of 2F-4spy furnished light brown crystals of [Cd(bdc)(2NO2-4spy)2(H2O)]⋅DMF (4). The coordination geometry of this compound is similar to that of 1 where Cd(II) is present in pentagonal bipyramidal geometry and the equatorial positions are chelated by the carboxylates of bdc linkers along with an aqua ligand, while the axial positions are occupied by the nitrogen atoms of the 2NO2-4spy ligands.

elements.content: The Cd(II) atoms are bridged by the bdc linkers to form a 1D polymeric chain along the b-axis through 2-fold crystallographic symmetry, and the coordinated water molecule is forming H-bond to the next chain to form an H-bonded 2D CP along a-direction. Unlike 1, these 1D chains are bent to each other along the chain by an angle of 139° (Figure ), which could be due to the steric hindrance caused by the nitro substituent. The 2NO2-4spy axial ligands interdigitated and the olefinic groups are aligned in an head-to-tail fashion with a distance of separation at 3.69 Å. Though this distance between the olefins is within the Schmidt’s topochemical criteria, surprisingly it has been found to be photoinert under UV light. Such unexpected photostability toward solid-state [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions has been noted before. In the case of 4, it is suspected that the inertness could be due to either steric hindrance or the electron withdrawing ability of the nitro group to prevent the formation cyclobutane ring. The exact role of NO2 group is yet to be understood in terms of photo inactivity.

Unlike 1, these 1D chains are bent to each other along the chain by an angle of 139° (Figure ), which could be due to the steric hindrance caused by the nitro substituent. The 2NO2-4spy axial ligands interdigitated and the olefinic groups are aligned in an head-to-tail fashion with a distance of separation at 3.69 Å. Though this distance between the olefins is within the Schmidt's topochemical criteria, surprisingly it has been found to be photoinert under UV light. Such unexpected photostability toward solid-state [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions has been noted before. In the case of 4, it is suspected that the inertness could be due to either steric hindrance or the electron withdrawing ability of the nitro group to prevent the formation cyclobutane ring. The exact role of NO2 group is yet to be understood in terms of photo inactivity.

elements.content: (a) A view is showing the coordination sphere of Cd(II) and the relative orientations of the equatorial planes between the adjacent polymeric chains. (b) Packing of 4 showing the relative orientations of 2NO2-4spy ligands between the adjacent 1D chains.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) A view is showing the coordination sphere of Cd(II) and the relative orientations of the equatorial planes between the adjacent polymeric chains. (b) Packing of 4 showing the relative orientations of 2NO2-4spy ligands between the adjacent 1D chains.

elements.content: In summary, we presented an unusual and interesting solid state [2 + 2] photoreaction in a hydrogen-bonded interdigitated 1D CP which has been synthesized by traditional solution synthesis as well as the mechanochemical route. The guest 2F-4spy molecules which are aligned in parallel with the coordinated 2F-4spy ligands furnished an infinite array of CC bonds. This 1D CP is expected to be photoreactive and the crystal structure packing analysis provided three possible reaction pathways. However, the time-dependent photoreactivity studies provided evidence that this proceeds in a stepwise manner, first between the host–guest ligands followed by host–host ligands. The end product of the photochemical reaction of the hydrogen-bonded 1D CP is expected to be a 2D layered CP. Interestingly, the recrystallized photoproduct under solvothermal conditions yielded a 3D pillared layered architecture with [Cd3(bdc)3] core comprising a rare bcg net. Obviously the composition changed during the recrystallization. A similar synthesis with the 2NO2-4spy yielded a similar 1D H-bonded interdigitated structure. Although the olefinic bonds between the 2NO2-4spy satisfy Schmidt’s criteria, this solid was found to be photostable under UV light, which could be due to the electronic effect or the steric hindrance of the nitro group.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we presented an unusual and interesting solid state [2 + 2] photoreaction in a hydrogen-bonded interdigitated 1D CP which has been synthesized by traditional solution synthesis as well as the mechanochemical route. The guest 2F-4spy molecules which are aligned in parallel with the coordinated 2F-4spy ligands furnished an infinite array of CC bonds. This 1D CP is expected to be photoreactive and the crystal structure packing analysis provided three possible reaction pathways. However, the time-dependent photoreactivity studies provided evidence that this proceeds in a stepwise manner, first between the host-guest ligands followed by host-host ligands. The end product of the photochemical reaction of the hydrogen-bonded 1D CP is expected to be a 2D layered CP. Interestingly, the recrystallized photoproduct under solvothermal conditions yielded a 3D pillared layered architecture with [Cd3(bdc)3] core comprising a rare bcg net. Obviously the composition changed during the recrystallization. A similar synthesis with the 2NO2-4spy yielded a similar 1D H-bonded interdigitated structure. Although the olefinic bonds between the 2NO2-4spy satisfy Schmidt's criteria, this solid was found to be photostable under UV light, which could be due to the electronic effect or the steric hindrance of the nitro group.

CCDC 987238–987240 for 1, 3, and 4 respectively) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Stepwise Host–Guest [2 + 2] Photoreaction in
